comment: succinct and to the point
Friendlier
The user didnt need to start the conversation, so there was less work to be done.
Same as before, does patch by itself
The programmer must call the bot, giving the programmer more control.
The bot on the left side needs to be manually called upon to make a patch for the commit, which allows the developer to only create patches for certain commits, not every one.
Its more descriptive and gives clear information on what went wrong and how to fix it
Easier to understand
Bot actions were triggered immediately, without need to wait for programmers trigger
Again, the right side is more simple and effective when trying to communicate what is happening. To me, this allows for ease of use and gets right to the point.
I prefer automatic test runs over me having to initiate the bot to run the tests.
I think it makes more sense for someone to call the bot before it acts, since this will force a real human to check the request.
should be done automatically if set up to do so
Again, I like that it kicks off automatically
More polite and conversational
Actions that could potentially add needless clutter to a repo should only be triggered by a human, and not automatically.
This appears friendlier than the left, although would be annoying if you had to see it a lot.
Short, clear description

It appears that this bot does not identify the presence of bugs (true/false), but rather the source of the bug in the code. This is not an operation that you would want to occur on every commit, as the developer may have additional context and not require the bots help. If the developer would like the bots help, then it can be easily requested.
I would rather the BugFinderBot start the conversation, to reduce the manual labour that I would have to do.
The left side seems to be more organized with what needs to be done in the request.
The right conversation is much more clear as to what is going on (and is more polite and optimistic, which matches more closely to the attitude of users on GitHub).
Prefer to call the bot myself if it will be wrong often.
The first sentence immediately explains the issue. This is preferable to allow skimming of the comments and extracting relevant information.
Had to request for the BugFinderBot
If a bot can fail on an action, such as producing a patch, it should be explicitly called to prevent cluttering of messages and wasting action time.

I believe that bots that automatically interact on their own can result in a lot of spam or false calls. In this case we see that the bots suggested fix was not an actual fix to a problem, and thus a bot capable of automatically generating patches and suggesting them could result in hundreds upon hundreds of patches if the bot malfunctions.
Its more clarifying in its response
The text is shorter and more to the point.
A human issued directions to the bot so left is more clear.
consice but more polite to new contributors
More concise
I do not think that a human comment is required to get the bot to run. I think the bot should be able to make comments automatically if they find something that needs attention.
Left side is automatic
Language on the left side is slightly more descriptive.
More straightforward
I prefer the option for a real life human to call the bot before it acts. Here it makes sense that a human should have to call the bot for bug checking, but it doesnt if it is a small error.
feels more polite and more human to read. and honestly, its more understandable
More clear
More clear what is needed
Because the patch is initiated by the developer.
More positive and polite feedback. Provides helpful suggestions
Luke703 started with generating a patch
because of starter command @BugFinderBot generate patch for this commit

comment: Provides more information on how to proceed. It is more polite
More explaination
Again, seeing who made the original commit is useful because I know exactly what commit the bot is referring to (since I can see the commit message and the user).
The left conversation gets straight to the point. It does not act like a person trying to have a conversation. To me, the left conversation is more clear.
It makes it obvious that a human issued the bot instructions rather than no info on what led the bot to attempt a patch.
The bot on the left must be called, giving the programmer more control.
I like how it automatically spots bugs for you, then asks if you spot something wrong.
prefer that the bot only starts after requested

It looks like on the left side the bot created the issue/PR on its own, and on the right it was triggered by a human action. I think that any action that could potentially add needless clutter to the repo (like for instance as in the example if the bot doesnt actually contribute useful code), it shouldnt be triggered automatically.
Its more cordial and gives a little more detail than the one on the right
It is more thankful and polite.
This way it seems that the bot is answering a request from a user, on the other side it seems almost like if the bot decided on his own to create a patch
The first sentence immediately introduces the issue. This makes it easier to skim the conversation history and extract the necessary information.
The right side addresses the creator of the PR directly and makes it clear that they need to do something, while the left simply makes a statement.
The bot is friendlier on the right
The fewer words the better. Especially when they relay the same “information”
Because the bot was prompted
The bot should automatically run without the need of a request from a developer.
Again, the right side is more human and approachable than the left. It still conveys the needed information but in a less abrasive and mechanical manner.
Again, the user didnt need to start the conversation.
The flakiness of the bot and lack of awareness of contextual information means that it should only be invoked manually.
I really dont see why anyone would enjoy such vebose messages from a bot. I sure dont. So for me the left side gets the point across and contains all the informations needed.

should be done automatically if setup to do so

comment: Again, the bot seems more human-like.
Because it is initiated by the developer
In general if you can say something with less words, you should. Also I like that the right side highlights not just the problem but also steps towards a solution.
The bot can generate a patch without needing to be asked so makes life easier
its more understandable and human-friendly
The bots explanation is much clearer and gives me a better understanding of whats going on.
Less communication between bot and user but information requested is concise
Flutter-dash-bot sounds polite

I prefer the right side because the person requests the bot to try a patch. Even though both attempts by the bot are incorrect, I dont want the possibility of the bot going out on its own to try to do fixes if it may consistently get them wrong. If that were the case, there could be a lot of invalid patches to go through.
More polite
This bot is friendlier (less scolding).

If the bugfinderbot tries to continuously find bugs on its own, but it continues to be incorrect, this will require a lot of editing on the programmers side. I would prefer if I have a concern and I need another set of eyes on the issue (such as a bots) to see if it can find some issue that I havent caught yet, but I want to have the choice of giving it the opportunity to find these bugs.

The bot shouldnt need to be requested. It should be automated for patch. Plus, why is the human so polite with the bot? They just need to leave comments so if someone else tries to track this issue, they will be able to see what the comments entailed. But I guess that is not the study here or maybe it is?

More human response that is less mechanical and abrasive than the straight to the point message on the right side. The left side is generally nicer (please close this) and is less attacking. The right side made me feel defensive about the pull request compared to the left side.
it is way more friendly, and it gives information on why no info is found. It needs you to read the CLA
I prefer automated patch finder over explicitly initiating patch finder.
It includes a starter command @BugFinderBot generate patch for this commit
The bots message is more relevant to the user, easier to understand.

Although there is more back and forth in the right conversation, TrishaOne has to manually ask the bot to generate a patch for the commit which makes sense since we may not want to create a patch for each commit, like the left side (I am assuming) would do.

Because there needs to be a manual validation step following each run of the bot, I believe it’s initiation should be manual as well and selective. Otherwise it seems to be creating more work for developers and not significantly improving their product.
The bots message on the right is more personal, direct, and easier to understand.
This message sounds more friendly
Since the bot is providing negative feedback, its attempts at sincerity may come off as cold or mocking, and may make it especially frustrating if the bot is mistakenly blocking a contributor.
I prefer the bot to be as straight forward as possible in its instruction. It doesnt need to pretend to be a human with being more polite, I know its a bot.

I feel that having the bot be called versus it running automatically is a matter of purpose in the repository and either is valid.
Both options were easy to understand
identical
I think both are fine. The left side is more friendly, while the right side is more abrupt but gets to the point.
TrishaOne generated a patch for this

depends on your needs. If you work with experienced programmers who know the works of BugfinderBot, you may want to be able to easily skip the bot
More concise, easier to read
I dont have a strong opinion on either

Not a strong preference. Given that the bot identified a false positive I would imagine that if the bot was to run automatically on every commit and then produce a large number of false positives developers might get frustrated and ignore its messages completely. It can be very time consuming for them to go through each error to validate its legitimacy. It’s best then if the developer can choose which commits they want the bot to run on - maybe more sensitive ones - and dedicate less time validating the bot’s results on trivial commits.
